Andy, I'm having some trouble understanding the question so I wanted 
to cl=
arify a few points before addressing it:

-What does it mean for a hidden n=
ode to "nothing more than duplicated 
substrate input and/or output nodes?"=
  What is meant by "duplicate?"  
Do you mean the activation function?  Bec=
ause other than that, what 
else is there that is duplicated?

-What is an =
"input-to-input" or "output-to-input" connection?   In 
general most ANN im=
plementations do not allow connections to go into 
inputs.  So what does th=
is mean?  And how does it relate to a hidden 
node, which is neither an inp=
ut nor an output?

-What is the "dimensionality of a node?"  A node exists =
in a space of 
some number of dimensions, e.g. 2 or 3 dimensions.  Is that =
what you 
mean?  Or do you mean the number of incoming or outgoing connecti=
ons, 
or something else?

-What is a "true" substrate hidden node?  I know =
you say it's "not a 
computational dupe," but I don't know what that means =
either.  A 
computational duplicate in my understanding would be a node tha=
t has 
the exact same weights on its incoming connections as some other 
no=
de.  But when would that ever be the case, and why is that not 
a "true" no=
de even if it was the case?

-What is a "clear dimensionality?"  Again, I a=
m not sure what you 
mean by dimensionality with respect to nodes?  Other t=
han being at 
some coordinate in the substrate, I don't know what dimension=
s there 
are associated with the node?

-What does this mean: "a) nodes onl=
y have one unique input, and b) an 
input has no activation function?"  Nod=
es can have any arbitrary 
number of inputs, so why do you say "one?"  Do y=
ou mean that all 
inputs are summed before being applied to the activation =
function?  
That of course is how almost all ANNs work, so how does this qu=
estion 
apply specifically to HyperNEAT?  

I know I'm just misunderstandin=
g, but I want to make sure I 
understand before trying to address the quest=
ion.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> I=
t would seem that the issue of substrate hidden nodes is mitigated 
> somew=
hat by the fact that in certain instances they are nothing 
more 
> than du=
plicated substrate input and/or output nodes, created for 
the 
> sole purp=
ose of handling input-to-input or output-to-input 
> connections, due to th=
e current limitation that a) nodes only have 
> one unique input, and b) an=
 input has no activation function. In 
this 
> case, the dimensionality of =
the clone node may reasonably carry 
with 
> it the dimensionality of the o=
riginal.
> 
> A true substrate hidden (i.e. not a computational dupe), woul=
d not 
> have a clear dimensionality associated with it. So the question is=
, 
> is there a meaningful way to present a true substrate hidden node 
to =

> a hypercube network, or simply have the hypercube network ignore 
the 
>=
 true substrate hidden nodes, and evolve the true substrate hidden 
> nodes=
 and associated connections to whatever, in the substrate 
> network separa=
te from the hypercube network (i.e. hypercube network 
> only operates on "=
b" & "c" for PSIs and PSOs, and their clones).
> 
> Other thoughts and/or c=
omments are appreciated!
> Thanks,
>    Andy Carl
> 
> 
>

hoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:

"P" in design space, comprised of the

fic inputs (PSIs);

Is;

arameters associated w/ PSOs;

ntified in (a) through (d) 
> above,

esign point P[i], a vector of 
> which

 resolution.

ubstrate Outputs: comprised of PSOs, "c" above;

comprised of auxiliary additional parameters

, "b" & "d" above;

es

r, how is the

ifferent hypercube networks depending on if the

 output), is a substrate input, hidden or

 substrate hidden nodes handled when the hypercube is

ssociated connecting substrate weight? (variation
